message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The dry, scaly lesions on the elbows that bleed when scratched suggests psoriasis which is characterized by increased keratinocyte proliferation. The patient's HIV status and medication history may contribute to his increased risk of developing psoriasis. Options A, B, and C are unlikely causes of the patient's skin findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The multiple, dry, scaly lesions on the elbows that are itchy and bleed when scratched are characteristic of psoriasis. HIV infection is a risk factor for psoriasis, and smoking may worsen the condition. The CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is slightly below normal, but still above the range in which opportunistic infections tend to occur. Among the options, only Increased keratinocyte proliferation is associated with psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of dry, scaly, itchy lesions that bleed when scratched is suggestive of psoriasis, which is characterized by increased keratinocyte proliferation. HIV infection and smoking are risk factors for psoriasis, and the patient's CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is not low enough to suggest an opportunistic infection. HPV-2 infection may cause genital warts but is not typically associated with dry, scaly lesions on the elbows. Malassezia furfur infection may cause pityriasis versicolor, but this typically presents with small, scaly, hypopigmented or hyperpigmented lesions on the trunk. Neoplastic T-cell infiltration may present with skin lesions but is less likely in a patient with controlled HIV infection and a high CD4+ T-lymphocyte count.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesions being dry and scaly, itchy, and bleeding with scratching suggests they are plaque psoriasis lesions. The patient’s HIV infection and smoking history may have contributed to the increased keratinocyte proliferation seen in plaque psoriasis. Neither HPV-2 infection nor Malassezia furfur infection are associated with plaque psoriasis. Neoplastic T-cell infiltration presents differently and is less common.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has HIV infection and the skin lesions are dry, scaly, itchy, and bleed when scratched, which are common symptoms of psoriasis. Additionally, psoriasis is associated with increased keratinocyte proliferation. HPV-2 infection can cause genital warts, but not dry, scaly, and bleeding lesions on the elbows. Malassezia furfur infection can cause pityriasis versicolor, which presents as small, scaly patches, and is not associated with bleeding. Neoplastic T-cell infiltration can cause mycosis fungoides, which presents with skin lesions that can resemble psoriasis, but it is not common in HIV patients with relatively normal CD4+ T-lymphocyte counts.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has dry, scaly lesions on his elbows that are itchy and bleed when scratched. These are characteristic of psoriasis, which is caused by increased keratinocyte proliferation. Psoriasis is also more common in individuals with HIV infection. HPV-2 infection typically causes genital warts, Malassezia furfur infection causes Malassezia folliculitis, and neoplastic T-cell infiltration would present with more generalized skin involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The skin lesions described match with the symptoms of psoriasis, which is caused by increased keratinocyte proliferation. HPV-2 infection can cause warts, and Malassezia furfur infection can cause pityriasis versicolor, but neither matches the symptoms described. Neoplastic T-cell infiltration would present with different skin manifestations. The patient's HIV infection may also contribute to the development of psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lesions on the elbows are characteristic of psoriasis, which is a condition of increased keratinocyte proliferation. HIV infection can exacerbate psoriasis, and smoking is also a risk factor. HPV-2 infection can cause genital warts, not dry scaly lesions on the elbows. Malassezia furfur infection causes pityriasis versicolor, which typically presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches on the trunk or neck. Neoplastic T-cell infiltration could present with skin lesions, but the presentation would be different from what is described in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The dry, scaly lesions on the elbows that are itchy and bleed suggest psoriasis, which is associated with increased keratinocyte proliferation. HPV-2 can cause genital warts but not skin lesions on the elbows. Malassezia furfur infection can cause seborrheic dermatitis but this typically affects the scalp, face, and upper trunk, and is not associated with HIV. Neoplastic T-cell infiltration can cause cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, but this typically presents as indurated patches or tumors, not scaly lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The scaly lesions on the elbows suggest psoriasis, which is characterized by increased keratinocyte proliferation. HIV infection is also associated with psoriasis. HPV-2 infection may cause genital warts, not scaly lesions on the elbows. Malassezia furfur infection can cause pityriasis versicolor, which is not characterized by scaly lesions that bleed. Neoplastic T-cell infiltration can cause cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, but there is no evidence of neoplastic infiltration in this case.
